question.title: Is it common practice in Java to add JPanels with custom layouts to a JFrame to organize components?
question.body:
I'm learning Java Swing and wanted to make sure I understand the common approach to building GUIs.

As far as I understand, the typical workflow is:

  1. Create a JFrame as the main window.
  2. Add one or more JPanels to the JFrame.
  3. Each JPanel can have its own layout manager (like BorderLayout, GridLayout, etc.).
  4. Components (like buttons, labels, text fields) are then added to these JPanels.

Is this approach considered good practice in real-world applications? Or is there a more modern or recommended way to organize Swing components?

answers.body:
As @VGR stated, your workflow is very common. Here's an example I created for another Stack Overflow question. I created a JFrame and two JPanels. One JPanel had a BorderLayout, while te other JPanel had a FlowLayout.

For a more complicated Swing project, I divide the code into model, view, and controller packages. Here's an example of a Connect Four game.

import java.awt.BorderLayout;
import java.awt.FlowLayout;

import javax.swing.BorderFactory;
import javax.swing.JButton;
import javax.swing.JFrame;
import javax.swing.JPanel;
import javax.swing.JScrollPane;
import javax.swing.JTextArea;
import javax.swing.JTextField;
import javax.swing.SwingUtilities;
import javax.swing.text.Document;

public class TextAreaBottom implements Runnable {

    public static void main(String[] args) {
        SwingUtilities.invokeLater(new TextAreaBottom());
    }
    
    private final int numberOfLines;
    
    private JButton sendButton;
    
    private JTextArea textArea;
    
    private JTextField textField;
    
    private String textAreaText;
    
    public TextAreaBottom() {
        this.numberOfLines = 10;
        this.textAreaText = "";
        
        for (int index = 0; index < numberOfLines; index++) {
            textAreaText += System.lineSeparator();
        }
    }

    @Override
    public void run() {
        JFrame frame = new JFrame("JTextArea Bottom");
        frame.setDefaultCloseOperation(JFrame.EXIT_ON_CLOSE);
        
        frame.add(createTextPanel(), BorderLayout.CENTER);
        frame.add(createInputPanel(), BorderLayout.SOUTH);
        
        frame.getRootPane().setDefaultButton(sendButton);
        frame.pack();
        frame.setLocationByPlatform(true);
        frame.setVisible(true);
    }
    
    private JPanel createTextPanel() {
        JPanel panel = new JPanel(new BorderLayout());
        panel.setBorder(BorderFactory.createEmptyBorder(5, 5, 5, 5));
        
        textArea = new JTextArea(numberOfLines, 40);
        textArea.setEditable(false);
        textArea.setFocusable(false);
        textArea.setText(textAreaText);
        
        JScrollPane scrollPane = new JScrollPane(textArea);
        panel.add(scrollPane, BorderLayout.CENTER);
        
        return panel;
    }
    
    private JPanel createInputPanel() {
        JPanel panel = new JPanel(new FlowLayout());
        panel.setBorder(BorderFactory.createEmptyBorder(5, 5, 5, 5));
        
        textField = new JTextField(40);
        panel.add(textField);
        
        sendButton = new JButton("Send");
        sendButton.addActionListener(event -> processInput());
        panel.add(sendButton);
        
        return panel;
    }
    
    private void processInput() {
        Document doc = textArea.getDocument();
        String input = System.lineSeparator() + textField.getText().trim();
        textField.setText("");
        textArea.append(input);
        textArea.setCaretPosition(doc.getLength());
    }

}

question_comments.body: JPanel as also JTabbedPane, JSplitPane, Not alwas necessary to introduce a JPanel for every JFrame, but see JFrame,setContentPane that creates a default container!
Creating a GUI With Swing
It is very common, and is the recommended way to get the overall layout one desires. In fact, not doing so is usually a mistake.

79573296.body: @Holger, thanks for the clarification, seeing it written in another way disoriented me.

@MarcePuente 1) a Runnable is not a thread 2) the current thread executing the main method is not the EDT. The run() method is executed on the EDT, that’s what this construct ensures, which is so common, that the official tutorial’s first example does it.
In my humble opinion, creating a thread (Runnable) on top of the current thread (EDT) only serves to muddy the code.
